abstract: Lunch at the Four Seasons in New York is not so much a meal as it is a performance. The restaurant is typically packed with power brokers and their admirers, assuring that any tete-a-tete gets widely noticed. So it was interesting to see Charles Prince, the chief executive of Citigroup, sharing a table there Wednesday with Sanford Weill, his predecessor at the banking giant.
lead_paragraph: Lunch at the Four Seasons in New York is not so much a meal as it is a performance. The restaurant is typically packed with power brokers and their admirers, assuring that any tete-a-tete gets widely noticed. So it was interesting to see Charles Prince, the chief executive of Citigroup, sharing a table there Wednesday with Sanford Weill, his predecessor at the banking giant.
